body:
Please give us more detail about your problem.
* Which task you need to import your metadata? Document classification? Sequence labeling? Sequence to sequence? Or all of them.
* If you often import external information, what kind of data format you use? Json?
* In the export data, take classification task as an example, you can find the document id, text, label, username. Are these not enough for your task?

Sure, thanks for rapid feedback!

My task now is to provide annotations for several steps in the ML pipeline for information extraction. But it is not limited to my setup. I will try to describe more precisely when this problem arises.

Let's imagine you have a not annotated dataset, which contains some metadata for each example: id, source, date for creation, user that grabs it, etc. Now you want to use `doccano` to annotate it. To be able to match the initial dataset with annotated you need, at least, some `external_id` that is imported with your dataset into the `doccano`. 

I see two usages for doccano:
* source of truth for datasets and annotation tool
* annotation tool

And for both of them you need to have some metadata to be stored with your examples. 
It does not matter what type of task you are accomplishing and what is the format of you dataset. I see this as a generally usefull feature.
It is not well documented but Explosion's annotation tool Prodigy does have this feature https://support.prodi.gy/t/how-to-incorporate-document-metadata/296/2

Thanks for your supplement. 
Your request does make sense. We do not consider such metadata like data source, user who grabs and so on. But doccano is a light annotation tool, it would be a nightmare to consider all kind of metadata. 

However, as you said, if there is at least the `external_id` as the unique key with imported file and export file, you can align the data by yourself after you get the annotated file. It is a good idea. We will consider your request.

>  user who grabs and so on. But doccano is a light annotation tool

We can take an approach used by Prodigy tool: just store all *other* fields into the json column in database at import phase and merge it on the export phase.

If we consider the `context` (many kinds of metadata), it may change the model classes a lot in `models.py`. I use 'light' to means a minimal modification to model classes and a few of fields in the database. Either way, I will talk with @Hironsan and decide which approach to use.
If you will need a PR I will happily provide you one.

Thanks @serzh, I saw your work on metadata feature, and it's great!  
Could you PR it after this #46 merged? This PR implement the json export feature from front to end. And the code may conflict with yours in the `views.py`. 
After it is merged, you could make a little modification in your code and then make a PR. Our reviewer will give the review.

Hi, @serzh, thanks for your patience. We have implemented the JSON export feature from front to end. Could you change your code accordingly? 
In order to follow a good GitHub collaboration workflow, there are some tips might be helpful. 

Usually, we use a new branch for feature development. But you developed directly on the master branch. This will cause confilct when you want to merge latest version to your forked repo. 

In order to rebase your forked repo (master branch) to the latest version of doccano. You should make a copy of your code, where the code related with metadata feature. 

```
# Add upstream
git remote add upstream https://github.com/chakki-works/doccano

# Fetch all the branches of that remote into remote-tracking branches,
git fetch upstream

# Make sure that you're on your master branch:
git checkout master

# Rewrite your master branch to make  your local doccano be the same with upstream/master 
git reset --hard upstream/master

# Make your forked repo same as the upstream
git push -f origin master
```
`git reset --hard upstream/master` will make your local version totally same with doccano master branch and delete the work you have committed. So, please make a copy before running the `git reset --hard upstream/master`.  

After you update your local master and origin master same with the upstream master, you can name a new branch like: `git checkout -b feature/metadata`. 

Then you could rewrite the metadata feature code in the `feature/metadata` branch. Here you will use the copied code before running `git reset --hard upstream/master`. 

As for the commit message, it would be great to add an issue prefix. For example, `git commit -m 'iss17: support for uploading json file'`. This is not mandatory, just for an explicit statement.

After you finish the development, you can run `git push origin feature/metadata` and make a PR from `serzh:feature/metadata` to `chakki-works:master`. 

You can check the detail here [How to Contribute to Doccano Project](https://github.com/chakki-works/doccano/wiki/How-to-Contribute-to-Doccano-Project)

If you have any questions feel free to ask us.
@BrambleXu Thanks, will start working on it

issue.title: Feature metadata

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
This PR introducec a concept of metadata: any additional keys or columns in the imported file that are preserved and exported in the metadata key or column on export. The main use-case is to be able to match exported data with your existing corpus by providing `external_id` in the imported file, although there are other use-cases. Corresponding issue #45 .

Here are some comments about this PR:
1. **CSV vs TXT**
It is not clear for me why we have csv format called a txt format. It is clear that txt format that is described on the "Import" page is a subset of the csv. Why don't call it just CSV? That is what I have done. And to preserver previous behaviour I have made the CSV header and text column in it required, unless it is one-column csv (previous txt format). If it is one-column csv it is assumed that the only column is the text column.

2. **Importing big files**
In the previous implementation the whole file was read into memory on the import phase. That may cause memory problems with really big files. To mitigate this issue I have made processing of this files to use generators and to use batched creation of the `Document` rows in database. I have made batch size to be configured by the `IMPORT_BATCH_SIZE` setting.

3. **Error handling** 
There was several places in the code where caught exceptions was not logged anywhere. To fix this I have added logging of them. Also I have added `django.contrib.messages` facilities to the `admin_base` template to show application level errors. For now it is used only for import feature, but I think that there are many other places where it will be appropriate.

4. **`Project` polymorphism based on its type** (not done)
We have 3 project types: document classification, sequence labeling and seq2seq. All of this types are represented as a single `Project` class with lots of `if-else`s on project type. It will be more better to use inheritance and `proxy` model to represent these polymorphic relations. It will be easier to extend, write and reason about.

issue.title: Read seq ann

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body: This PR addresses issues #11 and #45.  It adds a possibility to load and export JSON files for sequence annotations, and adds display of document ids (internal and imported).
